awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Bounded-Contention Coding for Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Interference in wireless networks often prevents nodes from receiving messages that are within transmission range. This is because communication occurs through broadcast channels rather than point-to-point links -- a node that is close to more than one transmitter receives a signal that is a mixture of the signals originally transmitted. Avoiding collisions basically requires some type of symmetry breaking among the nodes that want to transmit, to prevent them from transmitting at the same time, and has been the subject of many important studies.

This project will focus on wireless network scenarios in which the contention is bounded and introduce a framework for coping with collisions rather than avoiding them. It will consist of two main contributions. First, the PI will introduce a new coding framework for additive networks called Bounded-Contention Coding (BCC), which allows a receiver to uniquely decode colliding transmissions, and the PI will devise efficient codes within this framework. Second, the PI will design algorithms that use these codes for communicating in wireless networks, in order to solve many fundamental distributed problems.  The PI will complement this study with corresponding lower bounds in order to understand the limitations on communicating and computing in such an environment. The PI will also consider several extensions and modifications of the basic model, determine their impact on the algorithms, and propose new solutions for problems in these models as well.

The results of this project can have impact on the design of real wireless networks, in which bounded-contention scenarios are common.  For example, in a large-scale system of phones, only a few calls are typically active at one time. Another example is when nodes in a wireless sensor network receive measurement data from the environment periodically and send it to a central location in the network. The times at which the sensor nodes transmit their measurements could be scheduled in a way that bounds the number of concurrently active transmissions. In both of these examples, although the contention is limited, interference may still occur, implying the necessity to resolve colliding transmissions.  For examples such as these, our coding methods and algorithms can lead to new, efficient implementations, and our lower bound results can lead to a better understanding of the inherent limitations.

por.por_cntn:
The broad aim of this project was to develop algorithmic techniques
that would make it easier for algorithm and software designers to
design applications for wireless networks.  The work was theoretical,
focusing on obtaining the best algorithms to solve well-defined
abstract problems, according to well-defined cost metrics such as the
time and the amount of storage used.  The project began by focusing on
coding techniques for wireless communication, and broadened over time
to include other uses of coding in distributed systems (notably, to
reduce data storage cost in cloud storage services), and other types
of algorithms for wireless networks.

Specifically, the project began by developing new ``Bounded-Contention
Coding'' techniques for wireless communication that work well in
situations of low contention among senders.  These methods only
require each message to be transmitted once, with receivers able to
decode the meaning of intermingled transmissions from different
senders; this represents an improvement over previously-known
techniques such as probabilistic transmission and algebraic network
coding.  The costs depend on the amount of contention.  Using these
techniques, the investigators were able to produce new, efficient
algorithms for local and network-wide communication and computation
tasks.  The investigators analyzed the performance of the algorithms
mathematically, and also extended the results to more complex
platforms such as mobile networks and networks with multiple channels.

In a breakthrough later in the project, the investigators generalized
their methods to more powerful ``Bounded-Information Codes'', which
work in the presence of unbounded contention, as long as the number of
different messages remains bounded.  These new, more powerful methods were used to develop a large number of new wireless network
algorithms, for example, for symmetry-breaking problems such as leader
election, for approximation problems such as estimating the size of the network (or a local part), and for computational problems such as
determining the largest of all the input values in the network.

The project then considered other ways in which coding techniques
could be used to reduce the costs of solving problems in wireless
networks (and other distributed networks).  Specifically, the investigators considered the problem of emulating centralized shared memory in fault-prone distributed settings.  They developed a series of four successively-improved algorithms to implement such memory, with low time costs and with considerable improvements in storage and communication cost.  The algorithms made use of a well-known coding methods called ``Erasure Coding''.  The culmination of this work was a flexible ``two-layer'' algorithm, in which one layer is responsible for the data storage and coding, while the other layer manages the consistency of the various data versions.  This work was also complemented with lower bound results that express inherent limitations on the amount of storage that is required to guarantee the needed data-storage properties, even using arbitrary coding methods.

The project also developed and analyzed some wireless algorithms for
traditional wireless networks that do not support coding.  The problems considered in this work are similar to those considered for networks with coding, such as local and global broadcast and various types of network-wide computation.  Highlights here include the development of new abstraction layers for wireless network programming, such as a ``Reliable Local Broadcast'' layer and an ``Aggregation Tree'' layer.  These provide simple interfaces to facilitate construction of efficient higher-level algorithms and applications, while hiding complexities of managing communication
contention in low-level wireless networks.  Another highlight is an award-winning paper on leader election in wireless networks using flexible transmission power control.

Intellectual Merit:
This project has produced important contributions to the theory of
wireless networks, with likely applications to practice.  This work has built on ideas and techniques from several different mathematical disciplines, including coding theory, communication theory, probability theory, and distributed algorithms and lower bounds.

Broader Impacts:
The new Bounded-Contention-Coding methods and related techniques have the potential to lead to new types of algorithms for efficient programming of wireless networks.  This may enable the design of new
wireless networks with greater efficiency, reliability, robustness, and flexibility than those that currently exist.
